metadata.title: Establishment of an African green monkey model for COVID-19

abstract.text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is responsible for an unprecedented global 13 pandemic of COVID-19. Animal models are urgently needed to study the pathogenesis of COVID-19 and to 14 screen candidate vaccines and treatments. Nonhuman primates (NHP) are considered the gold standard model 15 for many infectious pathogens as they usually best reflect the human condition. Here, we show that African green 16 monkeys support a high level of SARS-CoV-2 replication and develop pronounced respiratory disease that may 17 be more substantial than reported for other NHP species including cynomolgus and rhesus macaques. In 18 addition, SARS-CoV-2 was detected in mucosal samples of all animals including feces of several animals as late 19 as 15 days after virus exposure. Importantly, we show that virus replication and respiratory disease can be 20 produced in African green monkeys using a much lower and more natural dose of SARS-CoV-2 than has been 21 employed in other NHP studies.

body_text.text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the etiological agent of coronavirus disease 24 2019 , emerged in Wuhan, China in late 2019 and rapidly swept the globe. As of May 16, 2020, over 25 4.4 million confirmed cases and 302,000 deaths have been reported worldwide [1] . The COVID-19 crisis has 26 inflicted an immense toll on human health causing profound socioeconomic effects that will linger for years to 27 come.
Vaccines and treatments against SARS-CoV-2 could drastically reduce COVID-19 transmission, saving

An ideal COVID-19 animal model would replicate all facets of human disease. Several animal species 41 including mice, hamsters, ferrets, and NHPs were found to support SARS-CoV-2 replication and displayed 42 varying degrees of non-lethal illness when the virus was delivered into the respiratory tract of these animals [7-43 13]. While each of these models has utility in the study of COVID-19, NHPs have the closest physiological 44 resemblance to humans allowing a better comparison of host responses to infection. This genetic similarity has 45 also contributed to the increased availability of reagents to perform in-depth analyses of the immune response.

Recently, the first studies evaluating the pathogenic potential of SARS-CoV-2 in cynomolgus and rhesus 47 macaques were performed. Rhesus macaques developed pneumonia and clinical signs whereas disease in 48 cynomolgus macaques was fairly mild indicating the former appears to better reflect more severe cases of 49 . These results suggest certain NHP species may serve as better models than others for 50 4 coronavirus infections. For SARS, the disease caused by SARS-CoV-1, African green monkeys (AGMs) were 51 found to support the highest level of viral replication, followed by cynomolgus macaques and rhesus macaques 52 when all three species were challenged in parallel [14] . Only AGMs had notable replication in the lower 53 respiratory tract following SARS-CoV-1 inoculation; necropsy of these animals indicated focal interstitial 54 mononuclear inflammatory infiltrates and edema in the lung consistent with human SARS. As SARS-CoV-1 and 55 SARS-CoV-2 share the same putative host receptor angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) [15, 16] , we 56 reasoned that AGMs might serve as a useful model for COVID-19.

Here, we infected AGMs with a low passage isolate of SARS-CoV-2 (SARS-CoV-2/INMI1-58 Isolate/2020/Italy) and evaluated their potential as a model for COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2/INMI1-Isolate/2020/Italy 59 was isolated from the first clinical case in Italy [17] and is the first V clade virus (GISAID) to be experimentally 60 inoculated into NHPs. We demonstrate AGMs mimic several aspects of human disease including a high degree 61 of viral replication and severe pulmonary lesions. This model can be used to conduct pathogenesis studies and 62 to screen potential vaccines and therapeutics.
We challenged six adult AGMs with 5.0 x 10 5 PFU of the Italy isolate of SARS-CoV-2 (SARS-CoV-2/INMI1-

Isolate/2020/Italy) by combined intratracheal (i.t.) and intranasal (i.n.) routes (dose divided equally). A cohort of 67 three animals was euthanized at 5 dpi, while the remaining three animals were held indefinitely. Blood from all 68 animals was sampled on days 0, 2, 3, 4, and 5, and continuing with days 7, 9, 12, 15, and 21 for animals held 69 past 5 dpi. No overt clinical signs of disease were observable in any of the animals, other than decreased appetite 70 compared to baseline (0 days post-infection; dpi) in 5/6 animals, and a brief period of elevated body temperature 71 suggestive of fever in two of three animals at 3 dpi (Supplementary Figure 1) . A biphasic increase in partial O 2 72 pressures were noted in two animals over the course of the study, but no overt changes in partial CO 2 pressures 73 in any animals were noted (Figure 1-A 18 thought to correlate with disease severity in hospitalized patients [19, 20] , we also measured levels of this 19 clotting factor. Fibrinogen levels surged in 4 of 6 monkeys indicating potential coagulation abnormalities in these 20 animals ( Figure 5-B ). This increase in circulating fibrinogen aligns with our gross pathology findings of substantial 21 hemorrhage in the lung of monkeys euthanized at 5 DPI. Collectively, these results indicate the host response 22 to SARS-CoV-2 infection in AGMs parallels that of humans.

Four animals seroconverted against SARS-CoV-2, including all three animals held past 5 dpi, with the 24 earliest detection of anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG occurring at 5 dpi in AGM-3, AGM-4, and AGM-6 (Figure 6-A). IgG 25 titers peaked at 15 dpi, with AGM-6 exhibiting low titers at 15 and 21 dpi compared to AGM-4 and AGM-5.
Neutralizing titers (50% plaque reduction values) ranged from 1:8-1:32 were evident beginning at day 5 in one 27 animal and all three animals followed to the study endpoint ( Figure 6 , B,C,D,E).

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2, and its astonishingly rapid evolution from localized outbreak to pandemic threat 31 has emphasized the importance of coronaviruses with regards to human health globally, particularly of those 32 clustering with lineage B betacoronaviruses. Accordingly, a necessity exists for the development of animal 33 models for SARS-CoV-2 which recapitulate the COVID-19 disease phenotype observed in humans. With regard 7 to NHPs, efforts to do so have been made using both rhesus and cynomolgus macaques [11] [12] [13] 21

AGMs challenged with an isolate of SARS-CoV-2 from Italy did not develop overt, debilitating clinical 39 illness; however, changes in leukocyte subpopulations, thrombocytes, and serum markers of acute inflammatory 40 processes indicated a systemic response to infection. Using surgically implanted temperature data loggers we 41 were able to detect elevated body temperatures in two animals 3 dpi, indicative of fever. Moreover, all animals 42 held past 5 dpi seroconverted, with two animals achieving high IgG titers (1:6400). The third animal held to 21 43 dpi never had an anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG titer above 1:200, suggesting a dampened humoral response in this 44 animal, and that immune arms other than humoral immunity may be important during SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Additionally, the potential for re-infection in humans with SARS-CoV-2 has been speculated, but the risk factors 46 or actual incidence are unknown. However, antibody titers to endemic human coronaviruses (e.g., 47 are reported to gradually wane and re-infection with the homologous virus has been reported [23, 24] .

An important aspect of the AGM model for SARS-CoV-2 infection is the development of pronounced viral 49 pneumonia. All AGMs in our study exhibited pulmonary consolidation with hemorrhage, varying in severity 50 between animals and lung lobes. We performed thoracic radiographs on all six SARS-CoV-2-infected AGMs; 51 however, the radiographs while consistent with work on SARS-CoV-2-infected macaques recently published by 52 others [11, 12, 21] did not reflect the degree of lesions and hemorrhage of the lungs seen at necropsy. It is our 53 opinion that the radiographs from our study as well as those from the other COVID-19 NHP studies do not 54 convincingly demonstrate SARS-CoV-2-induced disease. Specifically, opacities and changes observed in 55 radiographs could be nonspecific and due to atelectasis, poor inspiratory effort, and BALS collection procedures.

Important to this discussion, the current recommendation in humans is to not even use radiography for the 57 primary diagnosis of COVID-19. Notably, a recent study of 636 ambulatory patients with COVID-19 did not 58 detect any abnormalities in chest X rays of almost 60% of the cases [25] . The use of computed tomography (CT) 59 scanning or even plesmography techniques may be more informative for detailed pulmonary investigations using 60 animal models.

There was evidence of gastrointestinal involvement in the SARS-CoV-2-infected AGMs, which has been 62 reported in human cases [23] , as the putative SAR-CoV-2 entry receptor ACE-2 is expressed in the epithelium 63 of the ileum and colon [26] . However, while all animals in our study exhibited abnormalities within the small 64 intestine, we did not observe signs of gastrointestinal distress during the study course, with the possible 65 exception of decreased appetite in most animals.

Our data show that infection of AGMs with SARS-CoV-2 results in the release of inflammatory mediators 67 with similar immune signatures as human cases. Several groups reported that levels of IL-6, IL-8, and IL-10 68 correlate with disease severity in human patients [27, 28] . In this study, we observed increased serum levels of 69 these interleukins as well as other pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines elevated in human cases.

Moreover, we detected a rise in fibrinogen in a majority of monkeys, another prominent finding in human COVID-71 10 cases. Fibrinogen is implicated in thrombosis and vascular injury suggesting this discovery warrants further 72 investigation. Together, these results indicate the AGM model can be used to study the host response to COVID-

On specified procedure days (days 0, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 12, 15, 21) , 100 μl of blood was added to 600 μl of AVL viral 06 lysis buffer (Qiagen) for virus inactivation and RNA extraction. Following removal from the high containment 07 laboratory, RNA was isolated from blood and swabs using the QIAamp viral RNA kit (Qiagen).

Detection of SARS-CoV-2 load 10 RNA was isolated from blood and mucosal swabs and assessed using the CDC SARS-CoV-2 N2 assay 11 primers/probe for reverse transcriptase quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) [29] . SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detected using 12 One-step probe RT-qPCR kits (Qiagen) run on the CFX96 detection system (Bio-Rad), with the following cycle 13 conditions: 50°C for 10 minutes, 95°C for 10 seconds, and 45 cycles of 95°C for 10 seconds and 55°C for 14 30 seconds. Threshold cycle (CT) values representing SARS-CoV-2 genomes were analyzed with CFX Manager 15 Software, and data are presented as GEq. To generate the GEq standard curve, RNA from Vero E6 cells infected 16 with SARS-CoV-2/INMI1-Isolate/2020/Italy was extracted and the number of genomes was calculated using 17 Avogadro's number and the molecular weight of the SARS-CoV-2 genome.

Virus titration was performed by plaque assay with Vero E6 cells (ATCC CRL-1586) from all blood plasma 19 and mucosal swabs, and BAL samples. Briefly, increasing 10-fold dilutions of the samples were adsorbed to 20 Vero E6 cell monolayers in duplicate wells (200 μl). Cells were overlaid with EMEM agar medium plus 1.25%
Avicel, incubated for 2 days, and plaques were counted after staining with 1% crystal violet in formalin. The limit 22 of detection for this assay is 25 PFU/ml.

We incubated a standard 100 PFU amount of SARS-CoV-2 with two-fold serial dilutions of serum samples for 53 one hour. The virus-serum mixture was then used to inoculate Vero E6 cells for 60 minutes. Cells were overlaid 54 with EMEM agar medium plus 1.25% Avicel, incubated for 2 days, and plaques were counted after staining with 55 1% crystal violet in formalin.

Operations support of the Galveston National Laboratory was supported by NIAID/NIH grant UC7AI094660. 98 99 Figure 1 : Hematological features of AGMs infected with SARS-CoV-2. Blood was collected from AGMs on 87 procedure days (0, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 9, 12, 15, 21) . Partial pressures of CO2 and O2 were obtained using an iSTAT IgG binding titers were determined using traditional ELISA methodology where the antigen was whole infected 24 cell lysate (background subtraction was performed using virus negative cell lysate) and titers are represented as 25 reciprocal dilutions (A.). Antibody neutralization titers were also determined for sera collected 5 dpi (B), 7 dpi 26 (C), 15 dpi (D), and 21 dpi (E). Data plotted represents the percent reduction in plaque counts (average of 27 duplicate wells) compared to the average of three independent virus control plates (average plaque count across 28 all three plates = 75). Dashed lines on each graph indicate 50% neutralization compared to the virus control plates. 29
All plaque counts were calculated from duplicate wells at each dilution. 30

FIGREF0.text: 29 lives and brightening prospects for economic recovery. No licensed countermeasures currently exist, although a 30 number of clinical trials are underway. While clinical testing is a good predictor of preventative and drug efficacy, 31 caution is warranted with this approach due to the potential for disease enhancement. Vaccine candidates 32 against SARS-CoV-1, including inactivated whole-virus, recombinant DNA subunit, virus-like particle, and live 33 virus vector-based vaccines, induced an immunopathology following immunization and experimental infection of 34 mice, ferrets, and nonhuman primates (NHPs) suggesting hypersensitivity to virus components [2-5]. Given the 35 strong genetic similarity of SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV-1 [6], an appropriate surrogate for human COVID-19 is 36 needed to safely evaluate prophylactics. A careful assessment in animal models could reveal possible immune 37 complications elicited by vaccines and therapies prior to their release to the public. Moreover, animal models 38 could help shed light on important aspects of the disease in ways that are not easily addressed or feasible in 39 humans, such as how the virus spreads and interacts with the host immune system.

FIGREF1.text: ,B). Transient shifts in leukocyte populations and mild thrombocytopenia 74 were observed in all animals, most prominently during days 2-7 post-infection (Supplementary Table 1, Figure 75 1-C,D,E,F). Markers for renal and hepatic function mostly remained unchanged (< 2-fold increases in ALT, AST, 76 ALP); however, CRP, a marker of acute systemic inflammation, was elevated two to seven-fold in all animals 2-77 5 dpi (Table 1, Figure 1-G,H,I,J). Thoracic radiographs were taken on -1, 2, 3, 4, 5 dpi, and were shown to be each lobe. The most severe lesions were located in the dorsal aspects of the lower lung lobes 81 in all animals. A board-certified veterinary pathologist approximated lesion severity for each lung lobe 82 (SupplementaryTable 2) Small intestines in all monkeys were segmentally flaccid and distended with gas and 83 yellow liquid contents. Mild lymphoid enlargement was noted in one of the three monkeys. There were no other 84 significant gross lesions.

FIGREF2.text: Histologically, all three AGMs at 5 dpi developed varying degrees of multifocal pulmonary lesions. In the86 most severely affected monkey, histologic features of pneumonia include acute inflammation centered on 87 terminal bronchioles and numerous multinucleated giant cells with irregularly distributed nuclei. Continuous with 88 the terminal bronchiolitis was evidence of diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with hyaline membrane formation, type 89 II pneumocyte hyperplasia, pulmonary edema and pulmonary hemorrhage. Occasionally, small fibrous tissue 90 proliferations were noted within the terminal airways reminiscent of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia 91 (BOOP)-like lesions. Interstitial pneumonia was noted in the lesser affected regions of the lung along with 92 congestion and increased numbers of alveolar macrophages. In the less affected monkeys, pulmonary lesions 93 lack acute inflammation within the terminal bronchioles; however, interstitial pneumonia is present and in one 94 monkey, multinucleated giant cells with irregularly distributed nuclei were prominently displayed within 95 bronchioles. Colocalization of SARS antigen with pulmonary lesions were demonstrated with antibodies against 96 SARS N protein. Positive immunohistochemical labeling was noted diffusely within the cytoplasm of alveolar 97 macrophages, respiratory epithelium, type I pneumocytes and type II pneumocytes. One animal had only positive 98 immunolabeling in respiratory epithelium. Genomic SARS-CoV2 RNA was detected by in situ hybridization in 99 pneumocytes and associated with the alveolar macrophages within acute inflammation centered on terminal 00 bronchioles (Figure 3).

FIGREF3.text: We quantified viral load from mucosal swabs and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid collected on 02 procedure days by RT-qPCR and plaque titration (Figure 4). All animals had detectable quantities of vRNA and 03 infectious virus from nasal secretions beginning at 2 dpi, with viral titers ranging from ~2-4 log PFU/mL (Figure 04 4-A,B). Both viral RNA (vRNA) and infectious virus were detected from oral swabs from only three animals 05 (AGM-2, AGM-5, AGM-6) 3 dpi, and persisted in AGM-5 up to 7 dpi (Figure 4-C,D). Infectious virus was only vRNA nor infectious virus was detected by RT-qPCR of RNA from 09 whole blood or plaque titration of plasma from any animal, indicating a lack of circulating cell-associated or free 10 virus in the peripheral blood (data not shown). 11 Similar to human cases of COVID-19, systemic concentrations of a number of inflammatory cytokines 12 and chemokines were elevated following AGM infection. Serum levels of pro-inflammatory IL-8, IP-10, IL-12, and 13 monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP-1) peaked at 2 DPI corresponding to subsequent recruitment of 14 monocytes and neutrophils in the blood (Figure 1-D,E, Figure 5-C,D,E,F). Increased secretion of IL-6, IFN-beta, 15 and IL-10was also evident at this time point (Figure 5-A,G,H). Notably, IL-6 is thought to predict respiratory failure 16 in human COVID-19 cases and may serve as an effective immunological biomarker [18]. As IL-6 is a main 17 regulator of acute phase fibrinogen synthesis, and elevated fibrinogen and other coagulation abnormalities are

FIGREF5.text: virus (SARS-CoV-2/INMI1-Isolate/2020/Italy) employed was isolated on January 30, 2020 from the sputum 79 of the first clinical case in Italy, a tourist visiting from the Hubei province of China that developed respiratory 80 illness while traveling [17]. The virus was initially passaged twice (P2) on Vero E6 cells; the supernatant and cell 81 lysate were collected and clarified following a freeze/thaw cycle. This isolate is certified Mycoplasma and FMDV 82 free. The complete sequence was submitted to GenBank (MT066156) and is available on the GISAID website 83 (BetaCoV/Italy/INMI1-isl/2020: EPI_ISL_410545) upon registration. For in vivo challenge, the P2 virus was 84 propagated on Vero E6 cells and the supernatant was collected and clarified by centrifugation making the virus 85 used in this study a P3 stock.

Animals were longitudinally monitored 91 for clinical signs of illness including temperature (measured by surgically implanted DST micro-T small 92 implantable thermo loggers (Star-Oddi, Gardabaer, Iceland), respiration quality, and clinical pathology. All 93 measurements requiring physical manipulation of the animals were performed under sedation by ketamine. All 94 animal studies were approved by the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) Institutional Animal Care and 95 Use Committee and adhere to the NIH Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. were imaged with a portable GE AMX-4+ computed radiography system using a DRTECH detector 99 set at a 36 inch focal film distance. Images were captured and evaluated using the Maven Patient Image Software 00 in ventral dorsal (VD) and right lateral (R LAT) positions at 50 kVp and 12.5mA as previously described [22].01Chest radiographs were captured and interpreted by a double board-certified clinical veterinarian and veterinary 02 pathologist and reviewed by a MD board-certified radiologist.

FIGREF7.text: white blood cell counts, white blood cell differentials, red blood cell counts, platelet counts, hematocrit 26 values, total hemoglobin concentrations, mean cell volumes, mean corpuscular volumes, and mean corpuscular 27 hemoglobin concentrations were analyzed from blood collected in tubes containing EDTA using a Vetscan HM5 28 hematologic analyzer (Abaxis). Serum samples were tested for concentrations of albumin, amylase, alanine 29 aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), blood urea nitrogen 30 (BUN), calcium, creatinine (CRE), C-reactive protein (CRP), gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT), glucose, total 31 protein, and uric acid by using a Piccolo point-of-care analyzer and Biochemistry Panel Plus analyzer discs 32 (Abaxis). Partial pressures of CO2 and O2 were obtained using an iSTAT Alinity hematological analyzer (Abbott). at the indicated time points were tested for SARS-CoV-2-specific immunoglobulin G (IgG) 36 antibodies by ELISA. MaxiSorp clear flat-bottom 96-well plates (44204 ThermoFisher, Rochester, NY) were 37 coated overnight with a 1:1000 dilution of irradiated SARS-CoV-2 infected or normal Vero E6 lysate in PBS, pH 38 7.4 kindly provided by Dr. Thomas W. Ksiazek (UTMB). Sera were initially diluted 1:100 and then four-fold 39 through 1:6400 in 3% BSA in 1× PBS. After a one-hour incubation, plates were washed six times with wash buffer 40 (1 x PBS with 0.2% Tween-20) and incubated for an hour with a 1:2500 dilution of horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-41 conjugated anti-primate IgG antibody (Fitzgerald Industries International, Acton, MA). RT SigmaFast O-42 phenylenediamine (OPD) substrate (P9187, Sigma, St. Louis, MO) was added to the wells after six additional positive sample. End-point titers were defined as the reciprocal of the last adjusted serum dilution with were calculated by determining the dilution of serum that reduced 50% of plaques (PRNT50).

FIGREF8.text: based cytokine and coagulation immunoassays 58 Concentrations of immune mediators and fibrinogen were determined by flow cytometry using LegendPlex 59 multiplex technology (BioLegend). Serum levels of cytokines/chemokines and plasma levels of fibrinogen were 60 quantified using a Nonhuman Primate Inflammation 13-plex (1:4 dilution) or Human Fibrinolysis (1:10,000 61 dilution) panel, respectively. Samples were processed in duplicate following the kit instructions and 62 recommendations. Following bead staining and washing, 1500-4000 bead events were collected on a FACS 63 Canto II cytometer (BD Biosciences) using BD FACS Diva software. The raw .fcs files were analyzed with 64 BioLegend's cloud-based LEGENDplex™ Data Analysis Software. 65 66 Histopathology and immunohistochemistry 67 Necropsy was performed on all subjects euthanized at day 5. Tissue samples of all major organs were collected 68 for histopathologic and immunohistochemical (IHC) examination and were immersion-fixed in 10% neutral 69 buffered formalin. Specimens were processed and embedded in paraffin and sectioned at 5 μm thickness. For70IHC, specific anti-SARS immunoreactivity was detected using an anti-SARS nucleocapsid protein rabbit primary CA). Slides were developed with Bio-Red (Biopath) for 7 minutes and counterstained with 76 hematoxylin for one minute.

FIGREF9.text: 77 SARS-CoV-2 RNA in situ hybridization (ISH) in formalin-fixed paraffin embedded (FFPE) tissues was 78 performed using the RNAscope 2.5 high definition (HD) RED kit (Advanced Cell Diagnostics, Newark, CA) 79 according to the manufacturer's instructions. 20 ZZ probe pairs targeting the genomic SARS-CoV-2 spike protein 80 (S) gene were designed and synthesized by Advanced Cell Diagnostics (catalogue 848561). After sectioning, 81 deparaffinization with xylene and graded ethanol washes and peroxidase blocking, the sections were heated in 82 RNAscope target retrieval reagent buffer (Advanced Cell Diagnostics catalogue 322000) for 15 minutes and then 83 air-dried overnight. The sections were then digested with Protease III (catalogue 322340) at 40C in the HybEZ 84oven (HybEZ, Advanced Cell Diagnostics catalogue 321711) for 15 minutes. Sections were exposed to ISH 85 target probe and incubated at 40C in the HybEZ oven for 2 hours. After rinsing, the signal was amplified using 86 the manufacturer provided pre-amplifier and amplifier conjugated to alkaline phosphatase and incubated with a 87 red substrate-chromogen solution for 10 minutes, counterstained with hematoxylin, air-dried, and cover slipped.

TABREF0.text: ], with rhesus 35 macaques more closely exhibiting the symptoms of COVID-19 disease in humans. Given that AGMs have shown 36 utility as disease models for a number of respiratory pathogens (i.e., Nipah [22], SARS-CoV-1 [14]), we 37 investigated their suitability as a model for SARS-CoV-2 infection.
